RMP Executive Summary

1.	Facility Policy.  KAAPA Ethanol, L.L.C.A¿s corporate policies places the utmost importance on worker, public, and environmental safety, which is reflected in facility plans and training activities.  The owners, management and employees of the KAAPA Ethanol facility are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of hazardous materials.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department,  Kearney County Emergency Management (Local Emergency Planning Committee), and/or other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the public and the environment.

2.	Facility Information. The primary activity at the facility is the processing of grain into fuel-grade ethyl alcohol.  The ethyl alcohol manufacturing process involves the use of anhydrous ammonia and natural gasoline.  The natural gasoline is referred to as product denaturant and is used to make the ethyl alcohol unfit for human consumption.   


3.	Five-Year Accident History.  On March 4, 2004 KAAPA Ethanol had one denaturant spill within the tank farm.  A level indicated was found to be un-calibrated during initial build.  The lack of calibration caused the tank to overflow within the tank farm.  Parameters have been put into place to ensure no repeated circumstances.  All proper notifications were completed as required on the state and federal level.  There were no deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site.  There were no known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage as a result of the denaturant spill. 

4.	Emergency Response.  The emergency response program established by KAAPA Ethanol allows for personnel to respond to accidental releases of regulated substances in the event the release can be controlled using KAAPA Ethanol personnel and equipment in the area.  KAAPA Ethanol has identified additional resources to assi

st in mitigation, control and disposal of a release.  The local emergency response agencies will be relied upon to inform the public about the release. KAAPA Ethanol has developed an Emergency Action Plan outlining actions taken in the event of an accidental release of regulated substances as well as in the event of natural disasters.  The Emergency Action Plan is provided below for reference.  


5.	Accidental Release Prevention Program.   KAAPA Ethanol, L.L.C. plant has implemented several environmental, emergency, and safety programs at the facility.  These plans are crucial in our every day operation and procedures.  Daily, weekly, and monthly checks are completed that affect our ability to respond to emergencies, including a Health and Safety Plan.   Spill Prevention, Control and Countermeasure (SPCC) and Storm Water Pollution Prevention (SWPP) plans have been prepared and implemented, with updates completed as needed to ensure compliance and effectiveness.   All implementation is accordance with the applicable regulatory standards and time frames.  KAAPA Ethanol has developed a Prevention Program in accordance with the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68 for a Program Level 3 facility.  The facility conducts weekly and monthly training as part of our normal activities.  Training consists of regulated safety requirements.  A Process Safety Management (PSM) program has been implemented in accordance to regulation.  Products on site under the PSM program are anhydrous ammonia and natural gasoline.  The PSM program covers anhydrous system, distillation tanks and piping, and storage tanks utilized for anhydrous ethanol and denatured ethyl alcohol.   Safety inspections are completed regularly, utilizing in-house and outside expertise to conduct.  Periodic reviews are completed on plans and procedures in place, with scheduling for additional training as part of the review process.  

6.	Planned changes to Improve Safety.  Safety improvement is an on-going process at

KAAPA Ethanol.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the conditions of the facility.  There are no specific safety recommendations for implementation at this time.





EMERGENCY ACTION PLAN

I)	Policy Statement: KAAPA Ethanol, LLC believes that its employees are its most important asset, and that their safety and health are among its greatest responsibilities.  Therefore, this Emergency Action Plan has been established in compliance with the OSHA standard, Title 29 CFR 1910.38(a), and posted for all employees.

II)	Purpose: This Emergency Action Plan is intended to ensure the proper response to foreseeable emergencies and where necessary, ensure the orderly evacuation of employees from work locations to a safe area away from conditions that could be immediately dangerous to life and health. 

III)	Responsibility and Authority
   A)	The Program Coordinator  Tim Vogt has been assigned by the Chief Executive Officer to oversee:
    1)	The development, implementation and ongoing improvement of this Emergency Action Plan. 
    2)	Development and posting of the Emergency Action Plan Posters and Diagram
    3)	The monthly and annual inspections of all emergency equipment.
    4)	Periodic drills of the emergency action plan.
   B)	Visitors
    1)	The following procedure will be followed by all visitors/contractors entering the facility
      (a)	Monday A¿ Friday between 7:30 a.m. A¿ 4:30 p.m. all visitor/contractors will sign in and out at the administrative office ledger.  In the event work schedule starts or continues past normal office hours sign in will be completed at control room check/sign in ledger 
      (b)	Monday A¿ Friday between 4:30 p.m. A¿ 7:30 a.m. all visitor/contractors will check/sign  in and out at the control room ledger
         (i)	Contractors on site are required to supply information as to company name and total number of personnel on site at all times
      (c)	Contractors, if not accompanied by a KAAPA employee may

be given a radio to communicate critical or emergency situations in the event one arises.  This will be determined during project planning or pre-job briefing.

      (d)	If an evacuation is required, control room board operator will collect check /sign in ledger, located in control room as a means of identifying contractors on site.  Administrative office will collect check/sign in ledger and gather at the safe gathering location.  A role call will occur, in the event someone is presumed to be missing, attempts will be made through radio communication.  If unsuccessful  wait for emergency services to arrive before reentering the facility.
   C)	Incident Managers 
     1)	The following personnel have been assigned and trained to take charge in the event of an emergency, and depending on their availability at the time of the emergency, shall take charge in the following order:  
      (a)	Day Shift (Monday A¿ Friday)
         (i)	Tim Vogt A¿ Environmental/Safety Manager
         (ii)	Dave Gerhart A¿Plant Manager
         (iii)	Cory Ludwig A¿ Production Manager
      (b)	Night Shift, Weekends & Holidays
         (i)	Danny Allen A¿ Crew Chief
         (ii)	Randy Madson A¿ Crew Chief
         (iii)	Tommy Jameson A¿ Crew Chief
         (iv)	Casey Bantam A¿ Crew Chief
     2)	Their responsibilities will include, but not be limited to:
      (a)	Ensuring all emergency contacts has been made (emergency services, corporate, etc.).
      (b)	Ensuring all personnel has been safely evacuated by the Evacuation Wardens.
      (c)	Communicate and coordinate with emergency services upon their arrival.
      (d)	Overall responsibility for the management of the emergency.

   D)	Evacuation Wardens 
     1)	The following personnel have been assigned and trained to ensure, in any potential event or emergency that theyA¿re assigned areas are completely evacuated of employees, visitors and contractors during an actual emergency situation or mock drill.
      (a)	Adm

rgencies and Notification (alarm) Procedures 
  A)	Fire - In the event of a small fire, the closest employee will notify management and attempt to extinguish it himself/herself.  If a fire is felt to have the potential to be beyond the employeeA¿s control, they will shut down their equipment, activate the fire alarm system, (which is an intermittently alarm) and evacuate to the designated assembly point.  The Incident Manager on shift or the plant manager will ensure that the fire department is met at in front of the administrative office and directed to the site of the fire.
  B)	Tornado A¿ A weather alert radio is located in the office area where the control board operator can hear if a Tornado watch or warning is being issued.  Once a watch is issued the control board operator needs to notify everyone via radio that we are in a Tornado watch.  If a Tornado warning is issued we are to notify personnel via radio, and the incident manager only will turn a 2-way radio to channel 3 to listen to the local spotters.  
  C)	Hazardous Material Release A¿ If a release is discovered the incident manager on shift will be notified via radio and then notify Tim Vogt, the Environmental/Safety Manager.
  D)	Medical Emergency A¿

    1)Normal Business Hours
      (a)	Plant Emergency Control Room / Crew Chief, will call 911.  
      (b)	Administrative Building Emergency Stephanie Hemmer, will call 911 in the event the emergency is at or in the vicinity of the administrative building.   
      (c)	Notify Tim Vogt, Environmental/Safety Manager 
      (d)	Stephanie Hemmer, Administrative Assistant will notify the employeeA¿s emergency contact
    2)	Weekends, Holidays, & Nights
      (a)	Crew Chief will call 911
      (b)	Crew Chief will notify Tim Vogt, Environmental/Safety Manager immediately after calling 911
      (c)	If unable to contact Tim Vogt, Environmental/Safety Manager notify Corey Ludwig, Production Manager
      (d)	Crew Chief will notify the Tim Vogt, En

        (ii)	Night Shift, Weekends, & Holidays 
        (iii)	 Danny Allen A¿ Crew Chief
        (iv)	Randy Madson A¿ Crew Chief

    2)	Each Evacuation Warden will report to the Incident Manager at the gathering location.
    3)	Medical Emergency and First Aid Providers - All personnel have been trained to provide first aid treatment while awaiting emergency medical treatment.
  E)	Trainer:  Tim Vogt, Environmental Safety Manager has been assigned to train personnel in the Emergency Action Plan, as follows:
    1)	Current and New Employees shall know and understand:
     (a)	The emergency situations anticipated in the plan.
     (b)	How they will be notified of an emergency situation.
     (c)	How and when they should initiate the emergency action plan.
     (d)	Where to gather or take shelter in the event of an emergency situation.
     (e)	How and when to use a fire extinguisher.
     (f)	Types of Emergencies
    2)	Those with specific responsibilities within the plan shall be trained according to their responsibilities, including those with critical operation responsibility.
    3)	All personnel shall be re-trained anytime there is a change in the plan.
    4)	For hazardous material releases, 
    5)	The trainer shall maintain documentation of this training.

vironmental/Safety Manager or Corey Ludwig, Production Manager of the Hospital and ambulance that is transporting the employee.
      (e)	Tim Vogt, Environmental/Safety Manager or Corey Ludwig, Production Manager will notify the employee's emergency contact
      (f)	Tim Vogt, Environmental/Safety Manager or Corey Ludwig, Production Manager will ensure that the company drug testing policy will be adhered to if drug testing is required.

V)	Emergency Contact Phone Numbers
  A)	Fire - 911
  B)	Emergency Medical A¿ 911
  C)	County Sheriff A¿ 308-832-2805
  D)    Hazardous Material Release A¿ CHEM-TREC - 1-800-424-9300 

        Managers             
        Tim Vogt - Environmental/Safety Manager A¿                        
        Cory Ludwig - Production Manager A¿                       
        Dave Gerhart - Plant  Manager A¿ 
        Bodie Weeder A¿ Maintenance Manager A¿ 

VI)	Emergency Gathering and Shelter Locations
   A)	Fire or Hazardous Material Release A¿ In the event of an evacuation the primary meeting spot will be in the parking lot located on the North East side of the Administrative Building
   B)	Tornado A¿ In the event of a tornado warning all plant personnel are to take shelter in the grain pits or restrooms.  Administrative personnel are to take shelter in the basement restrooms of the administrative office building.  ContractorA¿s onsite during a tornado warning will be required to take shelter in the grain receiving pit or restrooms.   
VII)	Emergency Equipment Location List 
   A)	Fire extinguishers are located throughout the entire facility (see attached drawing)
   B)	Fire hydrants are located throughout the facility along the roadside (see attached drawing)
   C)	Fire hydrant guns located in the Ethanol truck/rail load out & around the tank farm
   D)	First aid kits are located
     1)	Administrative Office Supply Closet
     2)	In Break Room

VIII)	 The Program Coordinator will:
   A)	Coordinate annuals drills on e

ruck by flying debris.  
    5)	The Incident Manager will:
      (a)	Announce the all clear, or
      (b)	If there is any structural damage to the building, will have the Evacuation Wardens evacuate people to the Parking Lot on the North East Side of the Administrative Building. 
         (i)	The 2-way radios on channel 3 can inform the emergency services of an injury or fire located on site (These radios are to be used to communicate with emergency services for emergencies ONLY)
      (c)	Determine when it is safe to return to work.
         (i)	The local emergency services will notify KAAPA employees when it is safe to return to work.
  C)	Hazardous Material Release Procedure 
    1)	Contact the Incident Manager and Tim Vogt, Environmental/Safety Manager if any of the following materials are released: 
      (a)	Natural Gasoline (Denaturant) A¿ Tank Farm on West Side of Plant
      (b)	DCI-11 A¿ Tank Farm on West Side of Plant
      (c)	200 Proof Alcohol A¿ Storage in Tank Farm on West Side of Plant/Distillation Area
      (d)	190 Proof Alcohol A¿ Storage in Tank Farm on West Side of Plant/Distillation Area
      (e)	Caustic Soda A¿ Storage in Process Building
      (f)	Sulfuric Acid A¿ Storage outside of North Door of Process Building
      (g)	Anhydrous Ammonia A¿ Tank in Center of Property between Process Building & Silos
      (h)	Diesel A¿ Tank in Fire Water Building & Behind Warehouse
         (i)	Natural Gas A¿ Fenced in area South of Tank Farm, and throughout the facility
      (i)	If there is a fire or release involving Natural Gas, and it is safe, the employee can shut off the Natural Gas on the West Side of the Energy Center or at the Station South of the Tank Farm.
    2)	Evacuate people from immediate area, if necessary. 
    3)	The Incident Managers will:
      (a)	Evaluate the hazards of a release to determine the following:
         (i)	If the release can be safely handled by those working in the area with equipment normally a

ach shift for each emergency anticipated.  
   B)	Initiate the drill in the same manner as an actual event.
   C)	Pre-notify the following personnel to ensure no conflicts with important meetings or VIP visits.
     1)	Chuck Woodside A¿ Chief Executive Officer 
     2)	Dave Gerhart A¿ Plant Manager
     3)	Corey Ludwig A¿ Production Supervisor
     4)	Bodie Weeder  A¿ Maintenance Supervisor
   D)	Schedule the drills as follows:
     1)	Fire Drills A¿ In the fall or time permitting year around.  
     2)	Tornado Drills A¿ In early spring, when Severe Weather is at its greatest opportunity 
     3)	Hazardous Material Spills A¿ During a time determined to be least disruptive to production. 
   E)	Schedule a post-drill meeting with the Incident Managers and Employee Safety Committee to discuss any needed improvements in the plan. 
   F)	Make necessary changes to the plan, and re-train those affected by the changes. 
   G)	An actual event may suffice as one of the scheduled annual drills, as long as there is a meeting with the Incident Managers and Employee Safety Committee to discuss any needed improvements in the plan.  

IX)	Posting - The Program Coordinator will post for all employee to see:
   A)	The Emergency Action Plan Posters
   B)	The Diagram of the plant or worksite, and surrounding area showing:
     1)	Routes of exit
     2)	Gathering locations
     3)	Tornado shelters
     4)	Emergency equipment locations

X)	Action Plans for Potential Emergencies:
  A)	Fire Evacuation Procedures 
     1)	If a fire is discovered in its incipient (initial, early) stage: 
      (a)	Extinguish the fire with the provided equipment; and
      (b)	Immediately inform an Incident Manager of the incident.
     2)	If the fire has spread, or appears too big for ONE extinguisher to handle, or the area is thick with smoke:
      (a)	Sound the alarm activating the fire alarm system
      (b)	Call emergency services 911 
      (c)	Evacuate to the Parking Lot

on the North East Side of the Administrative Building 
      (d)	At the Parking Lot on the North East Side of the Administrative Building inform the Incident Manager exactly why you called for the evacuation and whether emergency services were contacts..
     3)	All employees will, upon hearing the alarm, evacuate to the Parking Lot on the  North East Side of the Administrative Building (see diagram)
     4)	Evacuation Wardens will, upon hearing the alarm:
       (a)	Ensure their areas are evacuated, telling people along the way where to gather.
       (b)	Report to the Incident Manager at the Parking Lot on the East Side of the Administrative Building.
     5)	The Incident Manager will:
       (a)	Ensure emergency services are contacted.
       (b)	If Natural Gas to the plant needs to be shut off designate an employee to close either the valve behind the Energy Center or our main station behind the Cooling Tower.
       (c)	Communicate and coordinate with emergency services upon their arrival.
       (d)	Notify the Environmental Health & Safety Manager.
       (e)	Account for Personnel
     6)	The Incident Manager will:
       (a)	Announce the all clear, or
       (b)	Determine when it is safe to return to work.
  B)	Tornado Procedures 
    1)	During a Tornado warning, personnel will be informed of the hazard via radio.  
    2)	Employees will take shelter in Grain Silo Pits or Basement of Administrative Building (see diagram).
    3)	The Evacuation Wardens will, upon hearing the notification, ensure their areas are evacuated, telling people along the way where to take shelter.
    4)	If time does not permit taking shelter in the designated areas, employees should:
      (a)	Gather in the lowest, center-most area possible.  (Avoid areas with large span roofs.)
      (b)	Move away from windows and exterior walls.
      (c)	Get under heavy machines, desks, tables, or other sturdy objects.  
      (d)	Remember the objective is to avoid being st
